title: 114_s3160
content: The Act may be cited as the "Securing our Secrets Act" or the "SOS Act". Definitions are provided in the Act. In this Act, "appropriate congressional committees" refer to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. The term "Department" refers to the Department of State. "Infraction" and "violation" have defined meanings from Executive Order 13526. The "Inspector General" pertains to the Inspector General for the Department of State. The term "intelligence community" refers to the definition in the National Security Act of 1947. The term "Secretary" specifically means the Secretary of State. SEC. 3. USE OF NONGOVERNMENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS. Employees of the Department must use only state.gov email accounts, Department-owned telephonic systems, or other Department-managed electronic communications systems for work-related communication. The Secretary must certify annually that all employees have access to these systems. The Secretary must certify annually that all Department employees have access to electronic communications systems. If certification cannot be made, a report must be submitted to congressional committees detailing the number of employees lacking access, reasons for the lack of access, steps taken to provide access, and steps taken to ensure work-related electronic communications. The Secretary of State may waive requirements for work-related electronic communications for up to 10 employees if it is in the foreign policy or national security interest of the United States. The Secretary of State can waive work-related electronic communication requirements for up to 10 employees if it serves the foreign policy or national security interests of the United States. The waived communications must be archived according to federal regulations and a written justification must be provided to congressional committees. Waivers are valid for up to 180 days and can be reissued. The Inspector General will develop an oversight plan within 90 days to ensure compliance with the requirements of multiple waivers issued by the Secretary under the Act. SEC. 4. REPORT ON SECURITY REVIEWS AND VIOLATIONS. The Secretary must submit an annual report to Congress detailing security violations, including unauthorized transfer of classified information, with information on the responsible employee, date, and description of each violation. The annual report to Congress must include details on security violations, such as unauthorized transfer of classified information, including the violated statute, actions taken by Department officials in response, disciplinary actions, remedial training, and justifications for not terminating employees with prior security violations. The annual report to Congress must include details on security violations, such as unauthorized transfer of classified information, actions taken by Department officials in response, disciplinary actions, remedial training, and justifications for not terminating employees with prior security violations. The report required under subsection (a) may not be made public by the Department and shall be transmitted in a way to prevent public dissemination of any information protected under the Privacy Act of 1974. SEC. 5. CLASSIFIED INFORMATION SPILLAGE. The Secretary appoints officials for training in detecting classified information spillage. Randomized sampling of emails is conducted quarterly to detect spillage among employees with security clearances. The Inspector General audits work related to safeguarding classified information and includes findings in semiannual reports to congressional committees. SEC. 6. REMEDIAL TRAINING. The Secretary must certify that all Department personnel with security clearances have completed emergency refresher training on handling classified information, including rules for electronic transmission. The curr_chunk discusses derivative classification, safeguarding classified information, handling foreign government information, processing FOIA requests, and challenges to classification status. The curr_chunk discusses the protection of classified information, the requirement for personal commitment from the Secretary, and the allocation of necessary resources for program implementation under Executive Order 13526 (2009). The curr_chunk outlines the implementation of programs for handling and protecting classified information, ensuring agency records systems are designed for sharing and safeguarding, designating a senior agency official, and including classified information management in personnel evaluations. It also includes penalties for violations and a certification requirement for employees receiving retraining. The curr_chunk emphasizes the importance of employees receiving retraining to ensure they understand the rules and responsibilities of accessing national security information. The Secretary is required to prioritize emergency refresher training for employees with security clearances at the Top Secret level and below. Employees with different levels of security clearance are required to undergo emergency refresher training. The Secretary has the authority to delay this training for up to 30 days for specific employees or groups if it is deemed necessary for critical foreign policy interests. The term "applicable rules and procedures" refers to any relevant Federal statutes. The term "applicable rules and procedures" includes Federal statutes, Executive Order 13526, current executive orders on classified information, the Foreign Affairs Manual, and Departmental guidance. SEC. 7. ENDURING TRAINING PROGRAM TO PREVENT MISHANDLING OF INTELLIGENCE INFORMATION. The Secretary must establish a training program to prevent the transfer of classified information to unauthorized systems. SEC. 8. PLAN FOR REFORMING RESPONSE TO REQUESTS FOR INFORMATION AND INFORMATION ARCHIVING. The Secretary must submit a plan within 90 days for completing reforms related to identifying classified information in documents under the Freedom of Information Act. The plan must include procedures for classification determination of intelligence community information, a training program on archiving electronic communications, and an annual sworn requirement. The plan required under this section includes procedures for classification determination of intelligence community information, a training program on archiving electronic communications, and an annual sworn affidavit requirement for employees to certify document archiving compliance. The Inspector General will report to congressional committees on the Secretary's implementation progress and information archiving efforts within one year of the Act's enactment.
